purpose: Definitions of tax terms for user education

deduction.definition: An expense or allowance that reduces your taxable income, meaning you pay less tax.
deduction.example: If you earn ₦1,000,000 and have ₦200,000 in deductions, you only pay tax on ₦800,000.

taxableIncome.definition: The amount of income you pay tax on, calculated as: Gross Income minus Deductions.
taxableIncome.example: If your gross income is ₦1,000,000 and deductions are ₦300,000, your taxable income is ₦700,000.

grossIncome.definition: Your total income before any deductions or taxes are applied.

paye.definition: A system where your employer deducts tax from your salary before paying you.
paye.explanation: If you're employed, your employer calculates and deducts tax from your salary each month and remits it to FIRS on your behalf.

chargeableIncome.definition: The income amount that is subject to tax after all deductions and allowances have been applied.
chargeableIncome.formula: Chargeable Income = Taxable Income - Personal Relief - Dependent Allowances

capitalAllowance.definition: A deduction for the depreciation (reduction in value over time) of business assets like equipment, vehicles, or buildings.
capitalAllowance.explanation: Instead of deducting the full cost of a business asset in one year, you can claim a portion of its value each year as it depreciates.

assessableProfit.definition: The profit from your business that is subject to tax, calculated as: Business Income minus Business Expenses minus Capital Allowances.
assessableProfit.formula: Assessable Profit = Business Income - Business Expenses - Capital Allowances

tin.definition: A unique 10-12 digit number issued by FIRS when you register for tax. It's required for all tax filings.
tin.howToGet: Register with FIRS (Federal Inland Revenue Service) to obtain your TIN.

nin.definition: An 11-digit number issued by NIMC (National Identity Management Commission). It's required for tax filing and other official transactions.
nin.howToGet: Register with NIMC to obtain your NIN. You can find it on your National ID card or NIN slip.

cac.definition: The government agency responsible for registering companies and businesses in Nigeria.
cac.explanation: If you operate a company or registered business, you must register with CAC and obtain a registration number.

firs.definition: The government agency responsible for collecting taxes in Nigeria.

nhf.definition: A mandatory contribution scheme for employees earning above ₦30,000 per month. Contribution is 2.5% of basic salary and is tax-deductible.
nhf.purpose: To provide affordable housing finance for contributors.

nhis.definition: A health insurance scheme. Contributions to NHIS are tax-deductible as medical expenses.

rsa.definition: A pension account where your retirement savings are held. Contributions to RSA are tax-deductible up to 25% of your income.
rsa.purpose: To save for retirement with tax benefits.

developmentLevy.definition: An additional 1% tax on assessable profit/income, separate from income tax. It funds national development projects.

jointFiling.definition: When two or more people file their taxes together, combining their income and deductions. Common for married couples or business partners.
benefits: May result in lower combined tax

progressiveTax.definition: A tax system where higher income is taxed at higher rates. In Nigeria, income is divided into brackets, and each bracket is taxed at its specific rate.
progressiveTax.example: First ₦300,000 at 7%, next ₦300,000 at 11%, and so on.
